    Hence show that

    ∑r=1ncos⁡(2pπrn+1)=−1\sum_{r=1}^{n} \cos \left(\frac{2 p \pi r}{n+1}\right)=-1 r=1∑n​cos(n+12pπr​)=−1

    where ppp is an integer in the range 1⩽p⩽n1 \leqslant p \leqslant n1⩽p⩽n.

    ∣Ax∣=∣A†x∣|A \mathbf{x}|=\left|A^{\dagger} \mathbf{x}\right| ∣Ax∣=∣∣∣​A†x∣∣∣​

    (ii) Show that A−λIA-\lambda IA−λI is also normal for any λ∈C\lambda \in \mathbb{C}λ∈C, where III denotes the identity matrix.

    (iii) Show that if x\mathbf{x}x is an eigenvector of AAA with respect to the eigenvalue λ∈C\lambda \in \mathbb{C}λ∈C, then x\mathbf{x}x is also an eigenvector of A†A^{\dagger}A†, and determine the corresponding eigenvalue.

    (iv) Show that if xλ\mathbf{x}_{\lambda}xλ​ and xμ\mathbf{x}_{\mu}xμ​ are eigenvectors of AAA with respect to distinct eigenvalues λ\lambdaλ and μ\muμ respectively, then xλ\mathbf{x}_{\lambda}xλ​ and xμ\mathbf{x}_{\mu}xμ​ are orthogonal.

    (v) Show that if AAA has a basis of eigenvectors, then AAA can be diagonalised using an orthonormal basis. Justify your answer.

    [You may use standard results provided that they are clearly stated.]

    (b) Show that any matrix AAA satisfying A†=AA^{\dagger}=AA†=A is normal, and deduce using results from (a) that its eigenvalues are real.

    (c) Show that any matrix AAA satisfying A†=−AA^{\dagger}=-AA†=−A is normal, and deduce using results from (a) that its eigenvalues are purely imaginary.

    (d) Show that any matrix AAA satisfying A†=A−1A^{\dagger}=A^{-1}A†=A−1 is normal, and deduce using results from (a) that its eigenvalues have unit modulus.

    Let AAA and BBB be complex n×nn \times nn×n matrices.

    (i) The commutator of AAA and BBB is defined to be

    [A,B]≡AB−BA[A, B] \equiv A B-B A [A,B]≡AB−BA

    Show that [A,A]=0;[A,B]=−[B,A];[A, A]=0 ;[A, B]=-[B, A] ;[A,A]=0;[A,B]=−[B,A]; and [A,λB]=λ[A,B][A, \lambda B]=\lambda[A, B][A,λB]=λ[A,B] for λ∈C\lambda \in \mathbb{C}λ∈C. Show further that the trace of [A,B][A, B][A,B] vanishes.

    (ii) A skew-Hermitian matrix SSS is one which satisfies S†=−SS^{\dagger}=-SS†=−S, where †\dagger† denotes the Hermitian conjugate. Show that if AAA and BBB are skew-Hermitian then so is [A,B][A, B][A,B].

    (iii) Let M\mathcal{M}M be the linear map from R3\mathbb{R}^{3}R3 to the set of 2×22 \times 22×2 complex matrices given by

    M(xyz)=xM1+yM2+zM3\mathcal{M}\left(\begin{array}{l} x \\ y \\ z \end{array}\right)=x M_{1}+y M_{2}+z M_{3}M⎝⎛​xyz​⎠⎞​=xM1​+yM2​+zM3​

    where

    M1=12(i00−i),M2=12(01−10),M3=12(0ii0). M_{1}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc} i & 0 \\ 0 & -i \end{array}\right), \quad M_{2}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & 1 \\ -1 & 0 \end{array}\right), \quad M_{3}=\frac{1}{2}\left(\begin{array}{cc} 0 & i \\ i & 0 \end{array}\right) \text {. }M1​=21​(i0​0−i​),M2​=21​(0−1​10​),M3​=21​(0i​i0​).

    M(a×b)=[M(a),M(b)]\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b})=[\mathcal{M}(\mathbf{a}), \mathcal{M}(\mathbf{b})] M(a×b)=[M(a),M(b)]
